A caterer named Tortoni invented the treat over a hundred years ago. CAPRI is another Italian word regularly butchered by English speakers who accent the last syllable: ca-PRI.  The Italians say CAP-ri.  They also say STROM-bo-li, which we pronounce Strom-BOL-i.

If you read the article, the tech is improving on led which can be tuned to match "natural" light spectrum unlike cfl.

Led is Totally different tech from cfl and renders it completely obsolete.

Prices are coming down on led, and it lasts 2.5x as long as cfl.

Efficiency is even better. Light output per watt is the key. You will save a lot over time with led, as it uses about 5 watts to create the same output as 100watt incandesent light. Cfl equivalent is like 20w.

Prices are not bad, just search amazon for "led warm white".

Led are 2-4 x as bright for the wattage as cfl, and 2.5x the life of a cfl. Also no mercury in manufacturing or glass tubes.

Simply put, Led is the future.

If every incandesent worldwide was replaced by led it would greatly decrease CO2 output.

This is further complicated this year as the Iowa caucus is at a strange time (right after the new year). Polling for the caucus is difficult, but made worse by the Christmas season. New Years day on Sunday. Some people back to work Monday and some off. Then the caucus Tuesday. Good luck with your last minute polling. Then the primary season is relatively quiet for several weeks until super Tuesday. So downstream effects are likely to also be skewed compared to other years.
Further, there is the spotlight effect. Mondale was well known in NH. Hart much less so. So for NH, suddenly Hart's name is being mentioned as the number two out of Iowa. It's reasonable to expect those not committed to Mondale to give Hart a look to see if they can support him. So under/over performing has an impact, but so does your relative name recognition. Huntsman doing better than expected out of Iowa would benefit more than Newt. Romney not doing as well as expected is hurt more than Santorum under performing.
Bottom line is that to get a meaningful result, you would likely have to control for a variety of factors (e.g. polling relative to holidays). Given the limited sample size, you are left with a potential for a false positive in whether the aligning of all the stars happen to match history vs having true predictive power.

I've been using compact fluorescents for almost 20 years now. Back in 1994 I did an almost complete changeover with incentives from my electric company. The cost to me was almost zero with the incentives at that time. There are some minor problems with them these days, but if one doesn't buy the absolute cheapest Chinese bulbs and pays attention to color temperature and color rendering index, one can easily buy a suitable CFL bulb. Those early bulbs I got (1994) were very descent in terms of color and their quality was very high (being of American and European manufacture).

Since then, I've moved on to LED for many of my light bulbs, starting in 2007. There was a learning curve, both on my part and the manufacturers' part. In the not too distant future, LED should be the predominate technology. Same issues as CFL with color and quality at the present time.

As to incandescents being banned, they aren't. First, there are exemptions for special purpose bulbs, such as oven and refrigerator use. Also for low wattage bulbs. Even for high wattage bulbs, incandescent bulbs aren't banned entirely, only low efficiency ones. I've noticed stores starting to stock halogen incandescents to replace standard incandescents in large quantities now. I started converting to halogens even before I started converting to compact fluorescents... back in the 1980s. Can't we at least advance to the 1980s?

Currently produced bulbs produce the same light.

In fact, in many cases, you can buy BRIGHTER bulbs that will safety work in older fixtures as they use less energy.

Here we do not equate the new standards with PC being shoved down our throats and are glad to be aware of better alternatives for the environment. When possible we have purchased & used some of the newer bulbs for several years in many fixtures.

BUT.... the points about fixtures & lighting strength are well taken. With the exceptions of a few lamps, all our lighting was installed when we built our home in the '70's. The new bulbs do not fit wall & dining room fixtures purchased then. In the case of 2 lamps which are used for general lighting (most of the time) & sometimes reading lamps, it is important to have bulbs which allow for the choice provided by the 3-way switch. In our bedroom we use the 50 watt, but as night comes, we sometimes have to up it to the 150 stage. As we get older, increased light is increasingly important, for safety in the home & activities such as reading, cooking. sewing, woodwork, even seeing well enough to give our dog his ear medicine.

Dark walls & window coverings may be fashionable, but you will not find them here, as there is an awareness of how light is eaten up by them. Many homes are older than ours and having to purchase more floor lamps or rewire behind walls is not a viable financial or safe option (more cords to be tripped on?), esp for those of limited means. (Being in the shrinking middle-class, we do not have the $$ to buy $1,000 worth of new fixtures & rewiring) Continued choice is the answer until there is improvement.
